The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

The Board of Trustees will recognize the contributions of Dr. Marilyn Brock, Interim President, and Ms. Kuni Hay, Vice President of Academic Affairs, to Evergreen Valley College and the San Jose-Evergreen Community College District.
	 
On January 11, 2011, the Board appointed Dr. Marilyn Brock as Interim President of Evergreen Valley College. Her appointment came at a time of leadership transition for the college. Dr. Brock immediately demonstrated her leadership skills and worked with the Chancellor's executive team in dealing with fiscal issues and budget reductions facing the district. She has guided the college through the accreditation process as EVC was put on accreditation warning and has served as chair for the district accreditation committee charged with reviewing Board policies. The Board wishes to express its appreciation for Dr. Brock's important contributions to the college and our district.
	 
Ms. Kuni Hay has served as Vice President of Academic Affairs at Evergreen Valley College, as Interim Vice President beginning in October 2005 and full time since April of 2006. Her major responsibilities include managing five academic deans and overseeing the 40 programs and certificates that are offered to the 12,000 diverse students enrolled in Evergreen Valley College. During her tenure, Vice President Hay's major accomplishments include leading the college through the accreditation process, project management for new building development, facilitating multiple partnerships with K-12 partners, and fostering the development of new innovative career technical education programs. Her leadership, professional standards and commitment will greatly be missed.

items.item_details:
In March 2011, the solicitation for food and vending services proposal was issued to twelve potential vendors identified by surveying other bay area community colleges and from vendors currently on the District’s list of potential vendors.  Of the twelve vendors, six attended the mandatory ‘bid-walk’ of which four submitted bids to the District.  The respondents were Corporate Chef, Fresh and Natural, Taher, and WM Café.
 
The four bids were evaluated by a committee that included the SJCC Business Services Supervisor, the Directors of Student Life from EVC and SJCC, the Director and the Assistant Director of Fiscal Services, and a Purchasing Agent.  Three of these vendors, Fresh and Natural, Taher, and WM Café, were selected to provide a presentation to the committee based upon the following criteria: Operations Experience (15%); Menu, Promotions, and Pricing (20%); Personnel Profile (10%); Fee and Scholarship Proposal (5%); Reference Checks (20%); Vending Machine Proposal (5%); Fiscal Responsibility (20%); and Office Proximity (5%).  
 
After receiving a presentation from the three potential food and vending service providers, the committee visited each provider’s operation on May 12, 2011 at local community colleges where they are currently under contract to evaluate their operation firsthand.  The highlights of the visits are:
 
WM Café – 10:30 a.m. at Mission College
Fresh and flavorful food
Breakfast special was priced high
One breakfast special and two lunch specials were available
Customers were generally happy with the quality and service; however, menu items were limited 
Fresh and Natural – 11:00 a.m. at Evergreen Valley College
A large selection of items with many low-priced "grab-and-go" items and a large salad bar 
Many daily food specials for breakfast and lunch 
"Grab-and-go" items displayed were fresh and hot with a fairly bustling business  
Customers were generally happy with the quality and service  
Taher – 12:15 p.m. at Cabrillo College
Stale pizza displayed
Very small salad bar
No specials 
Customers were generally dissatisfied with the quality and service and stated that items were typically not fresh, lacked selection, and specials were infrequent  
 
The evaluation committee recommends that the Board of Trustees approve and award the food and vending service contract to Fresh and Natural for a period of three (3) years, subject to satisfactory performance, with two optional one-year extensions, for compensation to the District as follows:
	 
Commission on gross Food Sales less sales tax:  10%
Commission on gross Catering Sales less sales tax:  7%
Commission on Vending Sales:  15%
Scholarships:  $2,000 annually split evenly between SJCC and EVC
In-kind Catering:  $1,000 annually split evenly between SJCC and EVC Presidents' Office
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve and award the contract for food and vending services to Fresh and Natural for a period of three (3) years, subject to satisfactory performance, with two optional one-year extensions.

The scope of this project is to address serious leakage and water intrusion that has been occurring over time in the utility tunnel on campus.  The utility tunnel has provided an essential infrastructure function for the campus utility systems.  Over time we have experienced serious leaks that have impacted the operation of the heating and cooling systems on campus.  This project will be required to maintain necessary services access and utility services for all buildings from the central plant.

items.item_details:
On July 13, 2010 The Board of Trustees approved the California Economic Development Department Green Innovation Challenge Grant Award received by Workforce Institute in the amount of $2,000,000.00.  The Institute has partnered with a host of organizations including PG&E, the California Building Performance Contractors Association, and the local workforce investment board, work2future, to identify and meet the short and long-term workforce needs of the Efficient Energy Home Building Performance market.  The innovative action plan utilizes a three-tiered training approach that reduces barriers to the deployment of efficient energy practices and upcoming incentive programs.  Cohort training programs include: Efficient Energy Outreach Specialist; Building Performance Institute (BPI), Building Analyst Certification; and Integrated Design Side Management for Power Engineers and non-engineering professionals.  Through these training programs the Green Innovation Challenge grant will train new professional workers who are essential to the job creation process, up-skill incumbent workers, and retrain unemployed/displaced workers.  The Green Innovation Challenge program will also work with local community-based organizations to form a grass-roots promotion effort that will drive the demand in the Energy Efficiency Home Building Performance market. The goals of the Institute’s Green Innovation Challenge grant award include: providing training programs within the 24-month grant timeline and stimulating demand in the Efficient Energy Home Building Performance market.
 
In an effort to meet the goals of the Green Innovation Challenge Grant Award, Workforce Institute is subcontracting with the following entities:
 
ICF International                                                          $275,000
Work2future                                                                $150,000
Cal. Building Performance Contractors Assoc.               $241,800
Workforce Incubator                                                    $  15,000

On November 2, 2010, the voters approved Measure G-2010.  CA Education Code 15252-4 requires that the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors adopt a tax rate for the Measure G-2010 bonds expected to be sold during Fiscal Year 2011-2012 and to levy a tax in Fiscal Year 2011-2012.  
	 
The voter approved ballot language identified the tax rate as $9.60 per $100,000 of assessed valuation. 
	 
The attached resolution requests that the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors establish the tax rate of $9.60 per $100,000 of assessed valuation, and to levy said tax on all taxable property in the District.
	 
The principal amount approved by the voters for Measure G-2010 is $268 million.  The District estimates that the sale of its first and second series of Measure G-2010 bonds to be $100 million. The District expects to issue it's first series of Measure G 2010 bonds in Fiscal Year 2011-2012.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the resolution requesting that the Santa Clara County Board of Supervisors establish the tax rate of $9.60 per $100,000 of assessed valuation for the Measure G-2010 bonds and to levy said tax on all taxable properties within the District.

The San José/Evergreen Community College District and Faculty Association, AFT 6157 reached  partial tentative agreement regarding salary savings.  The Faculty Association, AFT 6157 brought the tentative agreement to its membership where it was ratified.  The District and Faculty Association, AFT 6157 both expressed their understanding of the partial agreement.
	 
The District has an interest in addressing its ongoing fiscal stability and solvency through a variety of strategies as identified by the Board of Trustees on Feb 12, 2011.
	 
The District has an interest in seeking the following two strategies: a 3.5% salary savings and benefit savings of one million dollars, to provide the necessary expenditure savings to meet a 7% reserve level for 2011/2012 and incrementally address on-going budget shortfalls in subsequent years.
	 
Based on the best case state budget scenario, the union believes the following two strategies will meet the district needs:  a 1.4% salary savings and benefit savings of approximately one million dollars, to provide the necessary expenditure savings to meet a 7% reserve level for 2011/2012 and incrementally address on-going budget shortfalls in subsequent years.
	 
To ensure that the District can meet its ongoing financial obligations, the District and AFT 6157 shall continue discussions on salary savings based on the District’s 2011-2012 Tentative Budget which shall include the Governor’s May Revision, and the State’s 2011-2012 adopted budget. The subject of salaries effective July 1, 2011 will continue to be discussed when the parties reconvene June, 2011.
	 
The partial tentative agreement is attached.

items.item_details:
AB 515 (Brownley) which would authorize community college districts to offer fee-based extension courses for credit, passed off of the Assembly floor late Thursday June 2, 2011.  The bill had been brought up on Tuesday July 31, but fell six votes short of the 41 votes needed for passage. The bill was granted reconsideration and was brought back up on Thursday and gained support from seven more members to bring the vote total to 42, sufficient for passage. The fact that the bill was nearly defeated after passing out of Assembly Appropriations with only one “no” vote, is indicative of significant opposition. The bill will now go to the Senate, where there will likely be additional amendments.  
	 
It is recommended that SJECCD take an official vote not to support AB 515.  A resolution listing the rationale for this action is attached to this document.  It is important to note that districts already have the ability to offer “fee based” continuing education courses that would address some of the “capacity” concerns associated with budget related course reductions.  Finally, the major philosophical concern with AB 515 is the fact that it would represent the first step in the official “disinvestment” in state supported instruction in community colleges that represent the last vestige of open access for Californians.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve Resolution No. 061411-5 in opposition of AB 515 (Brownley) Credit Bearing Extension Courses.

items.item_details:
The District successfully passed Measure G-2010, a Proposition 39 Bond which carries a 55% voter threshold, on November 2, 2010 with 58.8% voter support.  The projects that were authorized for expenditure of bond funds, based on the Colleges' Educational Master Plans, are listed in the resolution calling for the bond election, which was adopted by the Board of Trustees on August 5, 2010.  Since that time, each College has completed their Facilities Master Plans (FMPs) and the Board of Trustees adopted the plans on January 25, 2011.
	 
The  Initial Master Project List presented for adoption shows for information purposes only the original project estimates of all potential projects identified within the FMPs.  However, this list totaled almost $450,000,000 while the value of Measure G-2010 is set at $268,000,000.  In order to right-size the allocations, the District and the Colleges identified those projects that were the highest priority.  Criteria included seismic deficiencies, infrastructure condition, instructional need, and College prioritization.  Each College used their participatory governance processes to review the proposed project lists, and District Council approved the allocations to each program entity and to the catastrophic contingency on May 12, 2011. The budget for each project is an estimate based on current costs and escalation factors.  However, the final costs of each project may be affected by factors beyond the Districtâs control. Projects identified within the FMPs, but that are not funded by Measure G-2010 and require additional resources, are also represented for information purposes only.
	 
In addition to estimating the soft costs (design, program management, specialty consultants, etc.) and construction costs for each project, every project has a 5% Project Contingency budgeted.  Each program also has a Program Contingency based on 5% of total estimated construction costs budgeted as a separate project. The District will carry a "Catastrophic Contingency" valued at 3% of the District-wide Bond Program.  These contingencies protect the integrity of the individual project budgets and programs, as well as the General Fund of the District, in the event there are excessive project costs.
	 
Once the Board approves the Measure G-2010 Initial Master Project List, each of the Colleges' Program Management Teams will work with the colleges to refine and revise, as needed, the list of projects, the scope of each project, and to validate each project budget.  If project budgets require revisions or if the Colleges' project priorities are revised over time, revisions to this list will be brought back to the Board of Trustees for approval before any changes will be implemented.  Deferred Maintenance, Technology and Equipment Projects, as well as Administrative Costs are also captured within the Initial Project List.  The approval of the Initial Master Project List will drive detailed scheduling exercises at the District and Colleges that will guide the timing and size of the initial bond sale.  It is estimated that the first bond sale will occur in December 2011.
	 
An Allocation Summary is also attached which illustrates Measure I, Measure G-2004, Measure G-2010 and State Capital Outlay resource allocations by entity.

WorkForce Institute received confirmation form Work2Future that funding will be allocated for the 2011/2012 program year.  The allocation allows for classified positions to be reinstated and selected layoffs to be rescinded. In addition, there is an opportunity to create a new classification and establish three (3) new positions.
		 
The Chancellor recommends the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution No. 061411-4

On September 2010 the Board approved a set of performance objectives for the Chancellor.  In turn, through the district's participatory process, these performance objectives were established as Chancellor Priorities.  This item addresses one such priority; namely, the development of a Strategic Communication Plan.  Full Capacity Marketing was retained to produce the Plan.  It is important to note that this project was not funded with "General Fund" dollars.  This presentation discusses the following:
	 
1) Methodology/Process for Development of the Plan
2) Findings and Recommendations
    a) Identification of Key District Target Audiences
	        i) Desired Communication Outcomes
       ii) Key Messaging
3) Recommendations Regarding Web Portal Redesign
	    a) Two-way proactive communication strategies
4) Questions and answers Regarding Next Steps
	 
It is expected that the proposed Strategic Communication Plan will provide key support for the development of a District Wide restructuring and reorganization work.
